content.text: What is truth? And why do some sentences about truth lead to paradox? The **Liar Paradox** — 'This sentence is false' — has puzzled logicians for millennia and drives research to this day.

content.definition: Consider: 'This sentence is false.' If it's true, then what it says is correct, so it's false. If it's false, then it's not false, so it's true. Contradiction either way.

content.text: Tarski showed that a consistent language cannot contain its own truth predicate — trying to define 'true-in-L' within L leads to paradox. Truth must be defined in a metalanguage.

content.title: Tarski's Hierarchy
content.note: Each level can only talk about truth at lower levels, avoiding self-reference.

content.definition: A theory of truth must entail all instances of: 'P' is true if and only if P. Example: 'Snow is white' is true iff snow is white.

content.text: Other approaches include: denying that the Liar has a truth value (gappy), accepting that it's both true and false (glutty), or rejecting the unrestricted T-schema.

content.question: What did Tarski conclude about truth predicates?
options: A language cannot consistently contain its own truth predicate
content.explanation: Tarski showed that defining 'true-in-L' within L itself leads to the Liar paradox. Truth for a language must be defined in a metalanguage — a hierarchy of languages.
